thinking.disposable_income: West Pullman has relatively low income levels with median income of $46,861 and 52.3% households earning less than $50,000. This suggests residents are price-sensitive to transportation costs and taxes.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With lower income levels and larger household sizes (2.7 average), discretionary spending is likely limited. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact household budgets given the high percentage of lower-income residents.
thinking.accessibility: Car dependency is high (63.1% drive alone) despite 23.4% having no vehicle. Transit usage is moderate at 12%. This suggests need for both affordable driving options and improved transit service.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritized proposals with lower sales tax (0.5%) to minimize impact on limited discretionary income. 2. Favored moderate driving fees ($0.50) over high fees ($1.00) given car dependency. 3. Selected lower transit fares ($0.75-$1.25) to help car-less households. 4. Balanced travel time improvements with cost burden. 5. Considered that 23.4% no-vehicle households need affordable transit options.
